abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and
            Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) Emergency
            Recovery Project for Pakistan were as follows: outcomes were
            not applicable; risk to development outcome was also not
            applicable; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was unsatisfactory. In early 2009,
            the Government of Pakistan (GoP) launched major military
            operations in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province (KP) and FATA to
            root out the local pockets of militants. Starting from the
            valley of Swat, bordering the tribal areas, the
            Government's military operations gradually moved
            westward. The offensive led to significant damage to
            physical infrastructure and services while creating a large
            population of internally displaced persons (IDPs) who lost
            their homes and livelihoods. Approximately 3 million people
            were displaced in KP and FATA in 2009.The Emergency Project
            was to set up a recovery mechanism that will provide cash
            grants directly to households affected by the militancy
            crisis and the flood crisis. The project design recognized
            that during the recovery process getting cash support to
            poor and vulnerable groups in a timely manner will improve
            their welfare, and that such assistance will be a prominent
            sign of the government's presence and support in a time
            of acute need. The project was strategically designed to
            provide short term relief in the aftermath of the
            devastating militancy crisis in Pakistan. The project was to
            support the early recovery phase (6-24 months) focusing on
            recovering livelihoods by promoting self-reliance and
            rebuilding livelihoods through cash transfers to households
            and reestablishing essential services such as health,
            education, water or sanitation, and primary infrastructure
            (road repair, transport, communication).
